selected_quotes: Detailed study of bleaching impacts on the coral calcification mechanism, via geochemistry of the skeleton
Great looking study showing the impact of bleaching on coral geochem
#Climate NPG: Response of coral calcification and calcifying fluid composition to thermally induced bleaching stre…

citation.abstract: Severe, global-scale thermal stress events like those of 1998 and 2016, are becoming more frequent and intense, potentially compromising the future of coral reefs. Here we report the effects of the 1998 bleaching event on coral calcification as well as the composition of the calcifying fluid (cf) from which corals precipitate their calcium carbonate skeletons. This was investigated by using the Sr/Ca, Li/Mg (temperature), and boron isotopes (δ(11)B) and B/Ca (carbonate chemistry) proxies in a Porites sp. coral. Following the summer of 1998 the coral exhibited a prolonged period (~18 months) of reduced calcification (~60%) and a breakdown in the seasonality of the geochemical proxies. However, the maintenance of elevated dissolved inorganic carbon (DICcf; >×2 seawater) and pHcf (>8.3 compared to seawater ~8.0) even during severe stress of 1998 indicate that a minimum threshold of high aragonite saturation state (Ωcf) of ~14 (~×4 seawater), is an essential pre-requisite for coral calcification. However, despite maintaining elevated levels of Ωcf even under severe stress, coral growth is still impaired. We attribute this to reductions in either the effective active volume of calcification and/or DICcf as bleaching compromises the photosynthetically fixed carbon pool available to the coral.
citation.title: Response of coral calcification and calcifying fluid composition to thermally induced bleaching stress

author.name: The Foster Lab
author.description: A collective of geochemists, loosely led by Prof Gavin Foster, using boron (and other) isotopes to reconstruct past climates. Views and opinions are Gavin's.

author.name: Justin Baumann
author.description: PhD student at UNC Chapel hill. Blogger/founder @underthecblog, coral biologist, organizing team member @SciREN_triangle. #scicomm, soccer, ultimate, Buckeyes

author.description: Post doc at University of Southampton, paleoclimatologist, isotope geochemist, foraminifera and deep sea coral enthusiast

blogs.title: The Achilles heel of coral growth is high temperatures, not ocean acidification
blogs.summary: The Achilles heel of coral growth is high temperatures, not ocean acidification, according to researchers from the ARC Centre of Excellence for Coral Reef Studies and The University of Western Australia. The research will be presented tomorrow in Canberra.

author.name: ARC Centre of Excellence for Coral Reef Studies
author.description: World-best integrated research for sustainable use and management of coral reefs.

news.title: High temperatures, not ocean acidification, is threatening the growth of coral

news.title: High temperatures, not ocean acidification is threatening the growth of coral
news.summary: The Achilles’ heel of coral growth is high temperatures, not ocean acidification, according to researchers from The University of Western Australia and the ARC Centre of Excellence for Coral Reef Studies.
